channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #119 - No Unicode in the subject line
item.description:
Hi,

Last week I had this little experience with various interesting Unicode characters in the Perl Weekly. On the web site it worked out well, but in the e-mail there were a few glitches. Most likely due to Mailman that I still use to handle the newsletter. (And it is a rather old version of Mailman, so I can't really blame it.) The subject line was missing the [Perlweekly] tag that Mailman should have included (and I hope it does this time again) and several people mentioned that they have not seen the heart in the subject line. I think the body of the message went through just fine.

item.title: We're Hiring Perl Software Developers - Grant Street Group
item.description:
We're a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications.
We're looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.
Email resume: 106686-CS-6734@grantstreet.hrmdirect.com

item.title: Back-End Blacksmith
item.description: Do you take pride in your craft and want to have fun() at the same time? Are you a geek? Join the team of iwantmyname from anywhere.

item.title: Would You Miss Autoderef in 5.20?
item.description: Autoderef was added to perl in version 5.14 and now it seems to be on the way out. chromatic asked your opinion if you will miss it. I think very few people have really used it. Have you?

item.title: Modular, Decoupled, Best Practiced, Well Designed, Bullshit
item.description: JT Smith suggests that making something work today is more important than 'doing it right'. Not everyone agrees with him.

item.title: Things we don't have #1
item.description: While CPAN has lots of modules solving many problems (multiple times), there are many problems that are not, or not well solved. Steven Haryanto started to put together a list of tools (libraries) available in other languages but not in Perl. In case you are looking for an problem to work on.

item.title: Acme-oop-ism Part Three: techniques
item.description: Toby Inkster continues his quest to unify the way we can use Moose, Moo and Mouse. One of his suggestion is to write for Moo. Code written using Moo works well with Moose as well, and the syntactic sugar alll three provide is quite similar. So if you use that, your code will likely work with all 3.

item.title: Planet Moose - October 2013
item.description: This is the regular write-up of Toby Inkster on the world of Moose and friends. This episode includes an interview with Upasana Shukla who implemented the Moose exception objects as part of her OPW internship.

item.title: Test repository for Git wrappers
item.description: Do you have a Gti wrapper? Does it work? Philippe Bruhat (BooK) has created a GtiHub repository with lots of weird commits to test against.

item.title: Grant Extension Request - Maintaining Perl 5
item.description: Tony Cook has requested an extension of $13,000 for his Maintaining Perl 5 grant.

item.title: YACT - Yet Another Conference Tool - Grant Report #1
item.description: Torsten Raudssus reports about the one week he worked on the grant since he started it in July.

item.title: DBD-ODBC 1.45 released to the CPAN + important warning
item.description: Apparently there is a serious unicode bug in DBD::ODBC which affects inserts into char/varchar columns.

item.title: Perl Meets Modern Web UI
item.description: This is the presentation of Bill Humphries at YAPC::NA about web frameworks for the client such as Backbone, Knockout, and Angular and how they work together with a Perl-based back-end.

item.title: Introduction to DBIx::Class
item.description: Doran Barton gave this introductory talk at the monthly meeting of the Salt Lake Perl Mongers.

item.title: Perl Catalyst 'Hamburg' Development Release 5 on CPAN, Final Call For Comments!
item.description: This is expected to turn into the stable Catalyst 5.90050 release. Go test it.

item.title: About LWP::UserAgent, https and proxy setup
item.description: Apparently LWP::UserAgent (and thus most Perl web clients that rely on it) cannot handle https requests via proxy. This bug was reported 10 years ago. Patches were submitted but the problem has not been fixed. Now Dominique Dumont explains the background of https and show how he proposed to fix the problem.

item.title: Writing Non-Blocking Applications with Mojolicious: Part 2
item.description: Joel Berger continued his article from last week.

item.title: Austrian Perl Workshop 2013
item.description: Thomas Klausner (domm) reports from Salzburg and shows us a T-shirt that can run.

item.title: YAPC::Brazil 2013
item.description: November 15-16, 2013, Curitiba, PR, Brazil

item.title: Nordic Perl Workshop 2013
item.description: November 23, 2013, Copenhagen, Denmark

item.title: London Perl Workshop (LPW 2013)
item.description: Saturday 30th November 2013 at Westminster University

item.title: German Perl Workshop (GPW 2014)
item.description: March 26-28, 2014, Hannover, Germany
